direction.name: direction

They sling the cases into the rear of the vehicle which in turn accelerates away hard, curving across the runway for another waiting plane.

direction.raw_text: .C., AERIAL - DAY The car threads its way through the Washington traffic, past the big administrative buildings, down tree-lined avenues, takes a turn into a gate.  As the car stops at the gate, the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Photo Interpreters power up light tables, stereoscopic viewers, zip across the floor in wheeled chairs. Flying switches, flickering lights, humming motors.  It's an eerie dance of technological black magic. Another pair of Interpreters loom out of the darkness, side by side, ghostly looking, their glasses reflecting the glare of the light table, like magicians staring into a crystal ball.

direction.raw_text: Aerial shots, flashing by.  Cuban countryside from 72,500 feet.  A MAGNIFYING GLASS swings down on its arm in front of us, magnifying the carpet of trees... and a row of six canvas covered OBJECTS among them.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, briefcase in hand, weaves his way through the empty, ornate hallways of the West Wing.  Past magnificent doorways, early American furniture, paintings.  He finally reaches a doorway, goes through into:

direction.raw_text: The doors open.  Kenny strides out onto a DIFFERENT FLOOR, the third.  He heads down the long, posh hall of the family quarters.  Fine furnishings, art.  The living White House. He approaches the double doors at the end of the hall guarded by a cluster of SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  An agent opens one of the doors.

direction.raw_text: Morning, Floyd.

direction.raw_text: Top o' the morning, Mr. President. The figure lowers the paper. It is PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY.  He's wearing boxers and a tank top.  Unshaven.  Bed-head. Kenny O'Donnell, former ward-pol and long-time Kennedy man, is his Chief of Staff...

direction.raw_text: : BUFFALO, NEW YORK A luxury hotel crowded with LOCAL POLS: the Democratic machine of Buffalo.  Beyond the open floor-to-ceiling windows, a CROWD.  The Pulaski Day Parade, a glimpse of '69s Americana.  High School bands blare Sousa.  The scene is deafening, boisterous.  Pols trail Kenny as he crosses the room: fast, tough, on-the-go.

direction.raw_text: We're putting up Potowski next time. Will you guys come out for him? KENNY Who else you got?

direction.raw_text: Everyone likes a good kid... And like that, a congressional candidate is made...  Kenny accelerates, leaving the Pols behind.  Suddenly, outside the windows, the crowd swells forward with a collective ROAR.

direction.raw_text: . PRESIDENT!  PRESIDENT KENNEDY!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny heads down the steps with New York Times Washington Bureau Chief, SCOTTY RESTON. Anonymous, they weave their way through the crowd for a police car on a side street.

direction.raw_text: How's my favorite President?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Busy.  But you've got his heart.

direction.raw_text: Three weeks before midterm elections? You need me.

direction.raw_text: Well.  There is a new civil rights initiative he wants to talk about.

direction.raw_text: I'm doing a piece on Skybolt.  I hear Macmillan's meeting with him in Nassau. Kenny just sighs as they make their way up to the police car. A Secret Service Agent opens the door for him, another is behind the wheel.

direction.raw_text: We're giving the Brits Polaris instead. But a story'll just aggravate things. Scotty stares at Kenny, determined.  Kenny looks away.  And his eye catches a tall, willowy BEAUTIFUL WOMAN.  She is talking, excited, embarrassed, to two more SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  What they're saying is lost in the noise. Scotty follows Kenny's gaze.  Then the two men share a look, a silent understanding.  Kenny glances at the Secret Service guy holding the car door, tilts his head at the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not today.  He's got tight schedule. The Agent nods, heads for the other Agents and the Beautiful Woman.  Scotty acts like nothing has happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretending there isn't a problem won't fix it.  He can clear the air on Anglo American relations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it, Scotty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him talk to me, he makes Macmillan look good, I print it, the British public likes it, Macmillan owes you. The formula's exactly what Kenny wants to hear.  He pretends to consider, pretends to cave as he gets in the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, you're in.  Half hour. Reston's won.  But so has Kenny, and he's made Scotty feel tough in the bargain.  People like Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the back seat, Kenny stares out the window at the parade goers.  The Secret Service Agents leave the Woman. Disappointed, the Woman turns and vanishes into the crowd. It's an eerie moment.  Something troubles Kenny, and he glances up at the sky.  A premonition.  But it's a clear, clear blue.  A day like this, all is right with the world...
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the table.  There are grim nods of agreement. The book is open to a PICTURE of an SS-4 BALLISTIC MISSILE. A photo from Moscow Mayday parade.  An icon of the nuclear age escorted like some devil-god to a holocaust...

direction.raw_text: . THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY The White House casts long shadows this gorgeous October morning.  Blue sky; the first flash of color in the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16TH, 1962.  DAY 1.

direction.raw_text: Briefcase and coat in hand, Kenny enters his office - and finds THREE MEN.  Standing there.  Thin-haired, bespectacled, academic-looking MCGEORGE BUNDY, 43, the National Security Advisor.  The two men in the background: PHOTO INTERPRETERS. Kenny hangs up his coat, sees the Interpreters' large black display cases.  And suddenly the world is slightly off kilter.

direction.raw_text: Hey, Mac.  You're up bright and early.

But the familiar route feels strange, and lasting an eternity.  Kenny eyes the package under Bundy's arm, its TOP SECRET stamp visible.

direction.raw_text: Morning, Floyd.

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just Cuba?  Okay, I got work to do, see you guys downstairs.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to me, you worthless piece of disloyal shit.  You will pull Daly's man on the circuit.  You owe your goddamn job to this administration. (beat, listening) There is a word you need to learn.  It is the only word in politics.  Loyalty. LOYALTY you motherfucking piece of shit! As Kenny THROWS the phone down at the receiver, and the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the Oval Office suddenly opens.  Kenny glances up.  President Kennedy stands there in the doorway. Kenny thinks he's reacting to the tirade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you looking at?  This isn't the blessed order of St. Mary the Meek. Kenny stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse us. The Assistants leave, shutting the door after them.  Kenny rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not as far as the election goes. The President lets Kenny by into...

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: where the Interpreters, their crewcut chief, ARTHUR LUNDAHL, 50's, and Bundy stare at him. They're surrounded by PRESENTATION BOARDS propped up around the fireplace.  The President's rocking chair and sofas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You used to look down a bomb sight for a living, Ken.  What do you see? In eerie silence, as all eyes follow him, Kenny makes his way among the presentation boards with the U-2 imagery, stops in front of the picture of the six canvas-covered objects.  It unleashes a wave of memories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hit a Nazi buzz bomb field in '45. (beat, incredulous) It looks like a rocket base... He puts his hand out to touch the image, then turns and looks to the President, knowing what they must be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Sunday morning, one of our U-2s took these pictures.  The Soviets are putting medium range ballistic missiles into Cuba. Shock.  Silence.  Kenny glances to the other men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They appear to be the SS-4: range of a thousand miles, three-megaton nuclear warhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ in Heaven...

result.heading: THE OTHER END OF THE ROOM

direction.raw_text: A bank of WHITE HOUSE OPERATORS work the switchboard, fingers flying, voices overlapping in a babble of:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please hold for the White House...Mr. O'Donnell for Secretary McNamara... White House Operator... please hold...

direction.raw_text: Kenny carries the phone with him as he paces hard from his desk to his window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The principals are assembling in an hour.  See you then. Kenny hangs up.  The President enters.  A beat.  And in that beat, there's a void.  The two men are off their emotional stride, trying to grope their way out of shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Bobby? Kenny nods, acknowledging the feeling
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should be here any minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. And we glimpse the chemistry of these guys by Bobby's absence.  It's like they're missing their third wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the hell are you? The President and Kenny hear him out in the hall.  And the tension goes out of them instantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In here! They turn to the door as BOBBY KENNEDY, 37, the President's younger brother/Attorney General, enters.  Bobby shuts the door behind him, falls into Kenny's chair, and clearly grappling with his own disbelief, is hushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, guys.  What the hell's Khruschev thinking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you have any indication of this from Georgi?  Any possible warning or sense of motivation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Complete snowjob.  And then we went out and told the country they weren't putting missiles into Cuba. (beat) By the way, you realize we just lost the midterms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who gives a shit about the midterms now? The Soviets are putting nuclear weapons ninety miles away from us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean there's something more important than votes?  Didn't think I'd live to see the day, Ken. The President paces away, grim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus.  I feel like we've caught the Jap carriers steaming for Pearl Harbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President strides down the plush hallway, Bobby and Kenny flanking him.  Unconsciously, all three men assume the same gait: confident, powerful, no longer disoriented. And before our eyes, the three men's game faces appear, and they become the hard-ass leaders of the United States. Secret Service Agents throw open the massive double doors to the Cabinet Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they enter.  The group of men at the long, ornate Roosevelt-era table, rise as one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, gentlemen. And the doors close on the eighteen men of EXCOM: The Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  They are the legendary "Best and Brightest." The President makes his way down the line: shakes hands with Secretary of State DEAN RUSK, 53, distinguished, with a soft, Georgian accent, a distant reserve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean, good morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President. The President leans past him, grasps the hand of the Secretary of Defense ROBERT MCNAMARA, 46, a gifted managerial genius... the price of which is a cold, hard personality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob.  Bet you had a late night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sleep is for the weak, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny greets Vice President LYNDON JOHNSON, 54, and ADLAI STEVENSON, 62, Representative to the U.N., intellectual, well-spoken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lyndon.  Adlai. The silver-haired war hero and politically savvy Chairman of The Joint Chiefs of Staff, GENERAL MAXWELL TAYLOR, 50s, shakes the President's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Max.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McCone's been notified and is coming back from the West coast.  Carter's here, though. He gestures to GENERAL MARSHALL CARTER, Deputy Chief of Operations for the CIA.  Carter nods to the President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S OVER THE OTHERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ex-banker, Secretary of the Treasury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studious Deputy Secretary of Defense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the detail-driven facts man, Assistant Secretary of Defense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 50s, Undersecretary of State.  Eloquent, a man of conscience. U. ALEXIS JOHNSON, Deputy Under Secretary of State.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: laid back, rumpled Soviet Affairs Advisor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deputy Director of the USIA. The President sits down at the center of the table, Rusk and McNamara to either side, and the others resume their seats. Bobby takes one of the over-stuffed chairs at the table. Kenny finds one along the wall behind the President, under the windows to the Rose Garden to TED SORENSEN, 30s, the President's legal counsel and speech writer.  They greet each other coolly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny. The room falls silent.  The President looks across the table to GENERAL CARTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  Let's have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur Lundahl heads our photographic interpretation division at CIA.  I'll let him and his boys take you through what we've got.  Arthur? Lundahl, standing at the end of the room with briefing boards, steps forward with a pointer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, as most of you now know a U-2 over Cuba on Sunday morning took a series of disturbing photographs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: US TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sweltering Cuban countryside.  Shouting SOVIET ROCKET TROOPS, stripped to the waist, glistening with sweat, machete a clearing under scattered, limp palm trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our analysis at NPIC indicates the Soviet Union has followed its conventional weapons build-up in Cuba with the introduction of surface-to surface medium-range ballistic missiles, or MRBMs.  Our official estimate at this time is that this missile system is the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandal.  We do not believe these missiles are as yet operational. A bulldozer TEARS through the undergrowth.  FILLING THE SCREEN.  A 70-foot long MISSILE TRANSPORTER creeps along in the bulldozer's wake like a vast hearse with its shrouded cargo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lundahl raps his second board: a map of the United States, Cuba visible in the lower corner.  An ARC is drawn clearly across the U.S., encompassing the entire Southeast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reports the SS-4 can deliver a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: megaton nuclear weapon 1000 miles.  So far we have identified 32 missiles served by around 3400 men, undoubtedly all Soviet personnel.  Our cities and military installations in the Southeast, as far north as Washington, are in range of these weapons, and in the event of a launch, would only have five minutes of warning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five minutes, gentlemen.  Five minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In those five minutes they could kill 80 million Americans and destroy a significant number of our bomber bases, degrading our retaliatory options.  The Joint Chiefs' consensus is that this is a massively destabilizing move, upsetting the nuclear balance. The President stares at Lundahl, and beating out each word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arthur.  Are. You. Sure? Lundahl looks around the room.  Everyone is hanging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. President.  These are nuclear missiles. The men come to grips with their own fears, own anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long until they're operational?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General Taylor can answer that question better than I can. General Taylor drops a memo on the table WHICH BECOMES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slapped down on a camp table.  A group of Soviet site ENGINEERS point and gesture as they study their ground from a shaded hillock.  CLEARING CREWS and SURVEYORS work and sweat in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: estimates ten to fourteen days. However, a crash program to ready the missiles could cut that time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor sees the grim looks all around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to stress that there may be more missiles that we don't know about.  We need more U-2 coverage. Kenny lets out his breath.  He catches Bobby's eye.  This is unbelievable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there any indication - anything at all - that suggests they intend to use these missiles in some sort of first strike?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at present, sir.  But I think the prudent answer is we don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do we have any sort of intelligence from
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on what Khruschev is thinking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Mr. President.  We don't.  We just don't know what's happening inside the Kremlin at that level.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They lied to us.  Two weeks ago Dobrynin told me to my face Khurschev had no intention of putting missiles into Cuba. They said themselves, this is our backyard. There's angry agreement.  The President cuts it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, I want first reactions. Assuming for a moment Khruschev has not gone off the deep end and intends to start World War Three, what are we looking at? Rusk glances to his team at the end of the table.  Ball, Johnson, Martin, Thompson and Stevenson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, I believe my team is in agreement.  If we permit the introduction of nuclear missiles to a Soviet satellite nation in our hemisphere, the diplomatic consequences will be too terrible to contemplate. The Russians are trying to show the world they can do whatever they want, wherever they want, and we're powerless to stop them.  If they succeed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will be Munich all over again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appeasement only makes the aggressor more aggressive.  Confidence in our security commitments around the world will falter, allies will become unsure in the face of Soviet pressure, and the Soviets will be emboldened to push us even harder.  We must remove the missiles one way or another.  It seems to me the options are either to build up the crisis 'til they give in, or we hit them.  An air strike. There's silence at the table.  Some nods.  Understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've worked up several military scenarios.  Before I ask General Taylor to lead us through the various options, I'd like for us to adopt a rule. If we are going to strike, we must agree now that we will do it before the missiles become operational.  Because once they are, I don't think we can guarantee getting them all before at least some are launched. And there it is.  The clock is running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir.  We need to consider... if we decide to act, there's a good chance we'll end up in a general war. The room falls silent.  The President leans back in his chair, studying the circle of men around the table, weighing them. Kenny and the others watch him in silence.  A long, dramatic pause.  A course that will change history is about to be chosen.  The President leans forward, folds his hands on the table.  Fated.  Grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's clear we cannot permit Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.  We must get those missiles out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny and Bobby follow the President down a path through the Rose Garden.  The shock of the morning has worn off.  The President stops, looks at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's going to matter what Khruschev's intentions are.  I tell you, right now... I don't see any way around hitting them. A long moment of silence as they move along again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we hit 'em, kill a lot of Russians, they'll move against Berlin.  They attack Berlin, that's NATO... and we're at war. The guys stop again.  The autumn day is bright, warm, alive. The air, the distant city sounds derail the relentless train of logic for a beat.  And in their faces we see that all three men, for the first time, feel the enormity of war, its shadow over everything.  It's only a couple of steps away. Steps that they're seriously contemplating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damned if we do, but if we don't, we're in a war for sure somewhere else in six months. Pained, the President turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No choice.  This is going to cost lives any way we go.  Do nothing, and it could be 80 million  of ours.  We have to get rid of those missiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There've got to be alternatives to just going out and bombing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right, Jack.  Taylor is saying we may have some time.  We've got to use it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So if there are alternatives that make sense - and I'm not saying there are - we need 'em.  Need 'em fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about the allies?  Congress?  I think we may need to start letting key people know.  And they're all scattered across the country for the campaign. We're going to need to get the U.N. staff in and warmed up.  Jesus... I don't even know if we've got secure communications with half our embassies since that the Soviets got that cryptographer of ours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't worry about everything right now.  We've got to figure out what we're going to do before we worry about how we do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other thing is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I know.  CIA and the military fucked us on the Bay of Pigs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're going to be pressing for a military solution soon.  We can't afford to let them ram their agenda down our throats.  We need to come with options other than air strikes so we have some sort of choice here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got a bunch of smart guys.  We lock 'em up together in there, kick 'em in the ass til they come up with options. Kenny and the President look at him.  Bobby nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too politicized with you in there, anyway.  They need to be able to stick their necks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be the principals, a couple of the key guys from each department: the Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  We'll call it EXCOM. Kenny snorts a laugh.  Bobby shoots him a cross look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  Has a ring to it.  Like F-Troop. The President stops.  Bobby and Kenny stop, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  Kenny and I only show for the meetings you call us into.  Impress us. And do it fast. (to Kenny) You're in charge of keeping this quiet. If word gets out before we know what we're going to do, there'll be panic. And it'll ruin any chance of surprise if we decide to hit them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we need to do a few things right away.  No Pierre.  He knows, the press knows. You're going to have to keep up your schedule - your movements are followed too closely.  And we need to get these guys out of the White House.  George Ball's got a conference room at State. (to Bobby) Reconvene over there this afternoon, come back here tonight. Bobby nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we should bring in Dean Acheson. He was fighting Soviets while we were still working the wards in Boston. The President nods his approval.  Looks at Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find him, Kenny.  We're going to need all the help we can get.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny moves hard and fast through the twisting warren of hallways and tiny offices which is the West Wing.  Suddenly, Scotty Reston pops out of a doorway behind Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Kenny!  Who died? Kenny glances over his shoulder at Scotty who points to a window.  A beat, then Kenny returns to look out the window. Outside, the West Wing Drive is FILLED WITH LIMOUSINES. A flash of dismay, but Kenny covers fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Way it's going, the Democratic Party. DNC strategy session.  If you can call it that. Scotty chuckles.  Kenny moves off, leading him away.  Kenny's assistant runs up behind him, holding out a slip of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir? Kenny tries to look him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Tuesday.  You said to call.  When do I get my 45 minutes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell you what.  We're in Connecticut tomorrow for Ribicoff.  I'll get you up front with him during the flight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir. Kenny turns, harsh
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? The Assistant eyes Scotty, holds his tongue.  Kenny takes the slips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number you asked for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ask for a lot of 'em.  Whose is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean Acheson's, sir. That shuts Kenny up.  Reston eyes the slip, then looks to Kenny's face.  And he knows something isn't right here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gotta go, Scotty.  See you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A car jolts to a stop.  The CAMERA PANS up over the sagging suspension, the government plates, the hood ornament revealing half of EXCOM inside.  Kenny stands nearby waiting for them. The doors open, and out they pile like a bunch of clowns: Bobby, McNamara, Rusk, Ball, Martin, Dioptric, Sorensen, Stevenson, and Nitze.  They're sitting in each others' laps, banging their heads on the roof, joking, but tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Screw secrecy.  You try having that fat ass sit on your lap all the way from Foggy Bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were excited.  I say no more. The gang falls in behind Kenny, trails him out of the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A steel door unlocks, swings open, and Kenny marches at the head of the wedge of men into a long tunnel.  It's the infamous old passage from the Treasury to the White House. Kenny and Bobby get a little ahead of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody agrees the diplomatic route is out.  It's too slow, and they'll have the missiles finished. Kenny looks at him.  Then there's only one alternative.  The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wipes through the ceiling to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  Where the brilliantly-lit flag flutters over the spotlit White House: their destination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: head of Tactical Air Command, stands at the head of the table with a presentation board. The men of EXCOM gather around Sweeney in their rumpled shirts, nursing coffee and cigarettes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have 850 planes assembling at Homestead, Eglin, Opa Locka, MacDill, Patrick, Pensacola and Key West.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An F-100 Super Sabre stands under lights on a taxiway.  The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , discovering the aircraft's sleek cockpit, menacing tiger-jaw paint job, the four 20mm cannons on its nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Due to the tropical foliage, the OPLAN calls for high-explosive and napalm loadouts for our ground attack sorties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The FLIGHT LINE where a full strike wing stands beyond this plane, pylons laden with weapons, GROUND CREW servicing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Other EXCOM members draw near the board, its order of battle, strike maps.  They're grim, but fascinated.  Empowering. Intoxicating.  Sexy.  Kenny sees it in the faces, even the President's.  Adlai does too, is upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still think there are diplomatic approaches we haven't considered yet. Kenny looks at Adlai.  The others around the room, embarrassed, don't respond.  The group has moved on and Stevenson hasn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have high confidence in the expanded air strike option. (beat) The problem, Mr. President, is that it's a short-term solution.  Khruschev can send more missiles next month.  The Chiefs and I believe we should follow up the air strikes with the full version of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An invasion...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.  We can be sure we get all the missiles, and we remove Castro so this can never happen again. Kenny looks around the room at the men, the murmurs of general agreement, senses the consensus building and is agitated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this the Chiefs' recommendation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.  Our best option is to commence the strikes before the missiles are operational.  The invasion happens eight days later. The President leans back in his chair, turns to the man at the far end of the table: DEAN ACHESON, 60s, former Secretary of State.  He sits silent, like some revered oracle, the architect of the American Cold War strategy of containment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean.  What do you think? Acheson arches an eyebrow, and when he speaks, his voice resonates throughout the room, powerful, smooth, hypnotic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, you have rightly dismissed the diplomatic option.  The Soviet will only tie you down in negotiation, and leave us short of our goal, the removal of the missiles. Negotiating will do nothing more than give them time to make the missiles operational, complicating the necessary military task we have at hand. Everyone in the room listens to him with rapt attention, his presence overshadowing the room, oracular:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the last fifteen years, I have fought here at this table along side your predecessors in the struggle against the Soviet.  Gentlemen, I do not wish to seem melodramatic, but I do wish to impress upon you one observation with all conceivable sincerity.  A lesson I have learned with bitter tears and great sacrifice. (beat) The Soviet understands only one language: action.  It respects only one word: force. Kenny stares at the old man.  Acheson's gaze finds his through the cigarette smoke.  Acheson's eyes travel to the President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I concur with General Taylor.  I recommend, sir, air strikes followed by invasion, perhaps preceded by an ultimatum to dismantle the missiles if military necessity permits. Taylor nods, vindicated.  The others murmur their approval. Bobby, at the table in front of Kenny and to his left, trades a dire look with Kenny.  This is happening too fast.  Bobby holds his head, looks about at the others, deeply distressed. The President sinks back in his chair, staring at Acheson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then it appears we have three options. Number one.  A surgical air strike against the missiles themselves.  Two, a larger air strike against their air defenses along with the missiles. Kenny eyes Bobby.  Bobby is writing something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And three, invasion. Bobby looks over his shoulder at Kenny, and REACHES BACK to him with a folded NOTE.  Kenny takes it, opens it. It reads NOW I KNOW WHO TOJO FELT PLANNING PEARL HARBOR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're certainly going to do number one; we're going to take out these missiles, so it seems to me we don't have to wait very long.  We ought to at least be making those preparations. Kenny gives Bobby a curt nod.  Bobby tilts his head at the President: pass the note on to him.  Kenny rises, slips the note in front of the President. The President unfolds the note, and we HOLD ON IT and his reaction as in the b.g., out of focus, Taylor speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir, we're preparing to implement all three options, though I must stress again, sir, there are risks to the strikes without the follow-on invasion. Bundy clears his throat.  Speaks from somewhere down the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to be clear, Mr. President, that we have definitely decided against a political track. The President folds the note away, glances at Bobby.  A beat, the President looks from Bobby to Acheson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean, how does this play out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your first step, sir, will be to demand that the Soviet withdraw the missiles within 12 to 24 hours.  They will refuse.  When they do, you will order the strikes, followed by the invasion. They will resist, but will be overrun. They will retaliate against a target somewhere else in the world, most likely Berlin.  We will honor our treaty commitments and resist them there, defeating them per our plans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those plans call for the use of nuclear weapons. (beat) And what is the next step? Acheson sits back in his chair, smooths his moustache.  A dramatic beat, and then his ominous pronouncement rings out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hopefully cooler heads will prevail before we reach the next step. A chill runs down Kenny's spine.  He looks in shock to the President.  The President remains calm.  But in place of the fated look the President has had, there's a hesitation.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: NOW I KNOW WHO TOJO FELT PLANNING PEARL HARBOR

direction.raw_text: Acheson strides down the hall, Taylor, Sweeney, Carter and Bundy swept along behind him.  Bundy is on the defensive, the others grim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If McNamara'd get off the fence...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamn it, it's obvious.  It's the only option.  That asshole, Stevenson.  We can't let this drag out or we lose our shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bombing them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember that the Kennedys' father was one of the architects of Munich.  The General is right.  There is only one responsible choice here. Bundy just nods.  Taylor grabs a door ahead for Acheson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's pray appeasement doesn't run in families.  I fear weakness does. And the men head into a stairwell going down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grimacing in pain.  He opens a pill bottle, takes two pills out.  He takes a whiskey in a shot glass from Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny finishes pouring him and Bobby a couple of more shots, discreetly turning a blind eye to the President's pain. The President returns from his desk, shirt untucked, disheveled, back stiff.  He eases into his rocking chair. Bobby lies sprawled on the couch.  Kenny sits down.  They all look at each other.  A beat, something like shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ Almighty... They burst out laughing.  An absurd, tension draining moment. They shoot their drinks, Kenny refills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me Irish, but I don't believe in cooler heads prevailing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Acheson's scenario is unacceptable.  And he has more experience than anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no expert on this subject, no wise old man. The President stares Kenny in the face, understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The thing is, Acheson's right.  Talk alone won't accomplish anything. Kenny considers the President, his face straight as he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then let's bomb the shit out of them. Everyone wants to, even you, even me. (there's a point) It sure would feel good. The President sees what Kenny's saying: it'd be an emotional response, not necessarily the intelligent one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, I'm as conniving as they come, but a sneak attack is just wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right.  And things are happening too fast.  It smells like the Bay of Pigs all over again. Bobby picks up some reconnaissance photos on the coffee table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As if dealing with the Russians wasn't hard enough, we gotta worry about our own house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight, listening to Taylor and Acheson, I kept seeing Burke and Dulles telling me all I had to do was sign on the dotted line.  The invasion would succeed.  Castro would be gone.  Just like that.  Easy. The President is rendered mute by a wave of pain.  Kenny and Bobby aver their eyes.  When it passes, the President is hushed, grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something...immoral about abandoning your own judgement. Kenny nods, moved.  The President reaches out for the reconnaissance photos Bobby's flipping through.  Bobby hands them to him.  The President looks them over.  And when he speaks, there's humility.  And resolve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't let things get ahead of themselves.  We've got to control what happens. We're going to do what we have to make this come out right.  EXCOM is our first weapon. (beat) We'll resort to others as we need 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17TH.  DAY 2 A LONG SHOT of an ENORMOUS CROWD thronging a bunting-trimmed platform.  The President, barely recognizable at the distance, and a cluster of political VIPS wave from it, smiling. Kenny steps INTO FRAME, back here at the fringes of the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't anybody in Connecticut have to work today? The crowd goes nuts.  Kenny paces, checks his watch, impatient to be done with the necessary diversion.  Kenny gazes off to his right and spots Scotty Reston, along with half the White House press corps suckered along.  Scotty catches Kenny's look. Kenny turns away, but Scotty comes weaving over.  The President continues on, but all we hear is Scotty and Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny!  What happened?  They didn't let me up front, said the President was on the phone the whole time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?  Who was he talking to?  Acheson? Come on, O'Donnell, everyone's wondering what's going on.  What's Acheson doing in town?  And don't give me some bullshit about DNC think tanks. Acheson's Mr. Cold War.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you ask him yourself?  You can have him on the way home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm giving you a chance here: talk to me.  You can influence how this thing unfolds. But Kenny stands there, mute.  Reston just shakes his head, knowing for sure something's up.  He turns and heads back for the press corps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny and the President climb the stairs to the Presidential plane, the crowd cheering him.  He gives a final wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheer up, you've neutralized the entire White House Press Corps for a day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: meets in George Ball's small conference room at the State Department.  Bobby, in shirtsleeves, paces at the head of the table, very, very alone.  All eyes are on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No.  No.  There is more than one option here.  If one isn't occurring to us, it's because we haven't thought hard enough. McNamara squirms.  The others react in frustration.  CIA chief JOHN MCCONE, sharp, tough, conservative, is harsh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes there is only one right choice, and you thank God when it's clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're talking about a sneak attack! How'll that make us look?  Big country blasting a little one into the stone age.  We'll be real favorites around the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby, that's naive.  This is the real world, you know that better than anybody.  Your argument is ridiculous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You weren't so ethically particular when we were talking about options for removing Castro over at CIA. And there's nothing Bobby can say to that.  He props himself up on the table, stares at it as if there's an answer in its shiny surface somewhere.  There is only the reflection of his own face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't let my brother go down in History like a villain, like a Tojo, ordering another Pearl Harbor. McCone, Acheson, and Taylor share a look.  The last resistance to airstrikes is crumbling.  Finally, Bobby looks up at McNamara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob.  If we go ahead with these air strikes... (beat) There's got to be something else.  Give it to me.  I don't care how crazy, inadequate or stupid it sounds. (beat, pleading) Give it to me. McNamara suffers under the gaze of everyone at the table, weighing the situation out.  And finally he ventures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six months ago we gamed out a scenario. It's slow.  It doesn't get rid of the missiles.  There are a lot of drawbacks. (beat) The scenario was for a blockade of Cuba.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : THURSDAY, OCTOBER 18TH.  DAY 3 INT. OVAL OFFICE - DAY Kenny enters the office from his side door in the middle of a debate.  Military uniforms dominate the room: General Taylor, General Sweeney, and a host of briefing officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The situation is worse than we thought. We count 40 missiles now, longer range IRBMs.  They can hit every city in the continental U.S. The President stares out the window at the Rose Garden, his back to Air Force Chief of Staff GENERAL CURTIS LEMAY, 60. Beetle-browed, arrogant, the archetypal Cold War general. Yet there is something about him, his intelligence perhaps, that suggests he's playing a role he knows and believes in. The only other civilians in the room are Bobby, Bundy and McNamara.  The pressure from the military is almost physical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, as of this moment my planes are ready to carry out the air strikes.  All you have to do is give me the word, sir, and my boys will get those Red bastards. The President continues staring out the window.  Kenny eases over to the desk, leans on it, arms folded, interposing himself between the President and the soldiers.  Bobby joins him, side-by-side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long until the army is ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've just begun the mobilization under cover of a pre-arranged exercise, sir. We're looking at another week and a half, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you can begin the strikes, now.  The plans call for an eight-day air campaign.  It'd light a fire under the army's ass to get in place. That makes the President turn around, stare at LeMay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General LeMay, do you truly believe that's our best course of action?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, I believe it is the only course of action.  American is in danger.  Those missiles are a threat to our bomber bases and the safety of our nuclear deterrent.  Without our deterrent, there's nothing to keep the enemy from choosing general nuclear war. It's our duty, our responsibility to the American people to take out those missiles and return stability to the strategic situation.  The Big Red Dog is digging in our back yard, and we're justified in shooting him. Taylor steps in softly, smoothly: good cop to LeMay's bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, we have a rapidly closing window of opportunity where we can prevent those missiles from ever becoming operational. The other options... He spares a look at McNamara, who watches the fireworks, arms folded, serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...do not guarantee the end result we can guarantee.  However, the more time that goes by, the less reliable the choice we can offer you becomes. The President, partially defused, looks from Taylor to McNamara.  LeMay steps forward, softer now, sincere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, the motto I chose for SAC is 'Peace is our Profession.'  God forbid we find ourselves in a nuclear exchange.  But if launched, those missiles in Cuba would kill a lot of Americans.  That's why I'm being such a pain in the ass about destroying them. Destroying them immediately.  Hell, even Mac agrees. Bundy is uncomfortable.  Everyone turns to him.  He nods. Kenny realizes he's been co-opted by the military.  McNamara does too, lets out a deep breath.  The President eyes Bundy, then paces out from behind his desk, walks up to LeMay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General, what will the Soviets do when we attack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. Kenny, Bobby and the President look at each other, unable to believe what they just heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.  Because the only alternative open to them is one they can't choose. His pronouncement hangs there in the air: ominous, dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those aren't just missiles we'll be destroying.  We kill Soviet soldiers, and they will respond.  How would we respond if they killed ours?  No, they will do something, General, I promise you that.  And I believe it'll be Berlin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LeMay walk out of the Oval Office with Taylor, Carter and their staffers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those goddamn Kennedys are going to destroy this country if we don't do something about this. There are dark looks on the faces of the other officers. They agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the meeting next door disperses, the President rummages through Kenny's jacket which hangs on Kenny's chair.  Kenny, bemused, holds out the package of cigarettes the President is looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping LeMay pushed you.  I wouldn't mind going a few rounds with him. The President glances up, takes the proffered smokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We knew it was coming.  I tell you, Kenny, these brass hats have one big advantage.  We do what they want us to, none of us will be alive to tell 'em they were wrong. Bobby, Rusk and Sorensen enter from the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, Gromyko should be on his way by now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need to go over what you're going to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's still no sign they know that we know about the missiles.  Been a lot of cloud cover; probably think we aren't getting any good product.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We keep 'em in the dark as long as we can.  But I sure as hell am going to test him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny comes out of the bathroom, and is buttonholed by the crewcut, bullet-headed Press Secretary, PIERRE SALINGER, in the crowded, busy hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, I'm getting funny questions from the guys in the press office.  As Press Secretary, I need to know.  What's going on? Kenny wheels back into his office.  It's filled with people. But he bends confidentially to Pierre's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're planning to shave you bald next time you fall asleep on the bus. (off Pierre's get-serious look) Sorry, Pierre, Gromyko just arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Press Corps throngs Kenny's tiny office, pushing and shoving for a vantage at the side door to the Oval Office, waiting for the Gromyko photo-op.  Kenny stands shoulder-to shoulder with Reston and Sorensen near the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are they going to discuss the military exercises going on in Florida? Kenny doesn't even blink, but Sorensen does a poorer job at hiding his reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Scotty.  This meeting's been on the books for months.  It's just a friendly talk on U.S.-Soviet relations. Fortunately, the conversation is cut short as a dozen
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: suddenly go off on a dozen cameras as the reporters crush in on the Oval Office, and Reston is swept forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : over the reporters.  The President, unsmiling, enters the room beside Soviet Foreign Minister, ANDREI GROMYKO.  Gromyko pauses for the photos: grim, dark haired, saturnine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny reacts.  At last, the face of the enemy.
direction.name: direction

The peoples of the world want to know why. We are told again and again of this so called incontrovertible evidence of offensive weapons in Cuba.  Yet we are not allowed to see this evidence.  Are your spy planes so secret you cannot share this evidence with us?  Some planes?! The audience laughs.  Zorin basks in it.  And then grows stern.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Adlai, don't let him off!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John?  It's Bobby.  Get ready to send your staffer in.  He's going to be coming out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .N. SECURITY COUNCIL CHAMBERS - CONTINUOUS But Adlai's tremors are not tremors of fear.  They are tremors of anger.  His voice goes hard and cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, sir.  Let me ask you one simple question.  Do you, Ambassador Zorin, deny that the U.S.S.R. has placed and is placing medium and intermediate range missiles and sites in Cuba?  Yes or no - don't wait for the translation - yes or no? The diplomatic world GASPS as Adlai drops all pretense of civility, all statesman-like grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: s excitement mounts.  In the chorus urging Adlai on, we find Kenny edge toward the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .N. SECURITY COUNCIL CHAMBERS - CONTINUOUS Zorin shoots Adlai a testy look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not in an American courtroom, sir, and therefore I do not wish to answer a question that is put to me in the fashion in which a prosecutor puts questions.  In due course, sir, you will have your answer. There's laughter at Zorin's refusal to be bullied: but it's nervous laughter, not the polite stuff of diplomatic tete-a tete.  The RUMBLE in the room grows louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are in the courtroom of world opinion right now, and you can answer yes or no.  You have denied they exist, and I want to know if I have understood you correctly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !  Fists in the air!  Bobby lets the phone dangle a beat, covers it.  And then he lifts it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John, I'll get back to you. He lowers the phone to the receiver.  Kenny shoots him a triumphant smile.  The President looks at Kenny, shakes his head, a big smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .N. SECURITY COUNCIL CHAMBERS - CONTINUOUS Adlai presses on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm prepared to present the evidence in this room, proving that the Soviet Union has lied to the world. And Zorin cracks.  He looks uneasily to his delegation.  They bend forward to consult.  Adlai sits back in his chair, draping his arms over its wings with the confidence of someone who knows he's kicked ass. Adlai looks around the room while he's waiting for his answer, managing not to smile.  The diplomatic world is scandalized.  At last Zorin regroups, lifts his head from his huddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you do not choose to continue your statement, the Chair recognizes the representative from Chile. The CHILEAN DELEGATE stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I yield my time and the floor to the representative to the United States. The room explodes in laughter.  Not just nervous any more, not just polite.  They're laughing at Zorin's parliamentary ploy blowing up in his face. Zorin's smile is gone, his smooth facade destroyed.  And he looks like the biggest fool in the world. Adlai stares at the beet-faced man with disdain.  At last, Adlai stands, gestures to the door to the hall behind him. The PHOTO INTERPRETERS come racing in with their briefing boards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then, ladies and gentlemen, since it appears we might be here for a while, shall we have a look at what the Soviets are doing in Cuba? The Delegates RUMBLE in interest, rise from their seats to approach Adlai.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: celebrates.  Phones ring at several of the chairs at the conference table. The President and Kenny meet as Bundy picks up a phone in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't know Adlai had it in him.  Too bad he didn't have this stuff in '52.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zorin must not have gotten instructions. Somebody in their Foreign Ministry's blown it big-time. Bundy steps forward, holding the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President... Kenny and the President turn to see what they already have heard in those two words: concern.  The room falls quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone in hand, McNamara paces at his post over the flag plot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the ship is called Groznyy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Soviet Tanker, Groznyy, breasts the heavy seas.  Armed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: race along the deck to makeshift sandbagged emplacements in the bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We lost track of it yesterday at nightfall.  We thought we gave it plenty of room when we moved the quarantine line back.  We just reacquired it. The CAMERA PANS to the left, revealing a U.S. DESTROYER racing up alongside a few hundred yards away, pounding up and over the swells, punching up a huge fan of spray from its bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It crossed the line hours ago. Admiral Anderson, on the phone on the level below, is tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hail them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep us posted, Bob. McNamara leans against the wall, closes his eyes in exhaustion and stress.  And when he opens the, we PAN AROUND TO REVEAL: A G-d-like view of the flag plot, covered with HUNDREDS OF SHIPS, PLANES AND MARKINGS. McNamara stares out at the bewildering tangle of symbols, living men behind each one.  Each tangle of red and blue symbols a powderkeg.  A G-dlike view indeed.  And it is far more than any one mere man could keep control of. And he begins to realize it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're kidding ourselves... And not only that, in his bleary, sleep-deprived fog, he begins to understand something happening down there. The CAMERA MOVES over the enormous map, over the scrolling cryptic numerology.  THE BUZZ of radio communications bleeds in from the background.  The overhead platform swivels on its motor, like the vast arm of some fate-writing god as the Watch Officer on it updates the movements of the ships. McNamara stares, at the verge of grasping something.  Through the door-crack of genius, he has the glimpse of some grander thing, some grander design.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well.  Load your guns. That starts McNamara from his fatigued reverie.  He goes to the railing, looks down on Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that, Admiral? Anderson turns, gazes up from his tier below, distracted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been hailing the Groznyy for the last hour, Mr. Secretary.  The Groznyy refuses to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carrying out our mission, Mr. Secretary. If you don't mind, we're very busy right now.  We need to be able to do our jobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Admiral, I asked you a question. Anderson holds the phone aside, turns around again, looks up at him, impatient.  His answer is hard, cold, dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to follow the Rules of Engagement.  The Rules of Engagement which the President has approved and signed in his order of October 23rd. Anderson listens again to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Captain, you may proceed.  Clear your guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What -- EXT. OCEAN, PUERTO RICO TRENCH - CONTINUOUS The Destroyer's forward 5-inch twin guns swivel, train on the Groznyy.  A beat.  They OPEN FIRE with an ear-splitting
direction.name: direction

result.heading: HUNDREDS OF SHIPS, PLANES AND MARKINGS

direction.raw_text: ripping the air in front of the muzzles, the Groznyy so close a miss isn't possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McNamara SHOUTS at Anderson, dropping down the steps to Anderson's level.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Watch Officers scramble to comply, chaos and shouting in the war room as a chorus if "Cease fire cease fire cease fire," goes up.  McNamara turns on Anderson, is in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, God help us. Anderson smashes the phone down, wheels on McNamara, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Destroyer's guns hammer away at the Groznyy, at point blank range... but the Groznyy IS UNHARMED. Suddenly, in the air above it appear BRILLIANT FLARES.  They light up the ship, brighter than the sun.  The destroyer isn't firing deadly rounds... it's firing harmless starshells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson gets in McNamara's face. ADMIRAL ANDERSON That ship was firing starshells. Starshells.  Flares, Mr. Secretary. Everyone's eyes are on the two men.  Only the chatter of teletype breaks the paralyzing silence.  McNamara blinks, looks down at the plot on the floor.  Anderson's voice drops to a deadly sotto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddammitt, I've got a job to do. You've been camped out up there since Monday night.  You're exhausted and you're making mistakes.  Interfere with me, you will get some of killed.  I will not allow that. McNamara looks away at the faces of the men in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Starshells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of our way, Mr. Secretary.  The navy has been running blockades since the days of John Paul Jones. McNamara turns back.  And all trepidation, embarrassment, hesitation are gone.  He coldly appraises Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe the President made it clear that there would be no firing on ships without his express permission. ADMIRAL ANDERSON With all due respect, Mr. Secretary, we were not firing on the ship.  Firing on a ship means attacking the ship.  We were not attacking the ship.  We were firing over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This was not the President's intention when he gave that order.  What if the Soviets don't see the distention?  What if they make the same mistake I just did? (beat) There will be no firing anything near
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soviet ships without my express permission, is that understood, Admiral?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I will only issue such instructions when ordered to by the President. (beat) John Paul Jones... you don't understand a thing, do you, Admiral? He passes his hand over the enormous plot below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't a blockade. McNamara, trembling with anger, awe, whirls to Anderson.  And his burgeoning insight is born - clear, hard and cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This, all this, is language, a new vocabulary the likes of which the world has never seen. This is President Kennedy communicating with Secretary Khruschev. McNamara JABS HIS FINGER OUT AT the plot, and -- -- the CAMERA RACES DOWN, TRACKING OVER IT, across the vast ebb and flow of information, the delicate ballet of symbols and numerology, this language of steel and human life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26TH.  DAY 11. On Kenny's T.V. Walter Cronkite reads the news to footage of a BOARDING PARTY going up a ladder to the freighter MARCULA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At 7:29 this morning, the U.S.S. Joseph Kennedy stopped and boarded the Soviet charter vessel Marcula. The Boarding Party wears dress whites and is UNARMED.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a 3-hour inspection, the Kennedy signaled no contraband found.  Cleared to continue.  Pentagon spokesmen expect the next encounter. Kenny, who turns from the T.V. as the door to his office opens.  Rusk walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, we need to see the President. Something's happened. Kenny reacts to Rusk's enigmatic expression.  And out from behind Rusk steps JOHN SCALI, the ABC News Correspondent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the CAMERA FINDS an under-strength, ad hoc EXCOM - Kenny, Bobby, Taylor, Bundy, Sorensen, McCone, Ball and the President.  Guarded hope all around.  The short, balding, pugnacious Scali looks discomfited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have lunch with him maybe once a month.  Way he talks, he acts like he knows Khruschev personally, but he's never elaborated.  I've used him as a source in a couple of stories. Kenny paces behind the gathered men around the President's desk, listening, mind going a million miles an hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The FBI has identified this Alexander Fomin as the Soviet Resident, the KGB equivalent of one of our station chiefs. He's their highest ranking spy in this country.  And he knows John's a friend of mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the trademarks of a back-channel overture. Kenny eyes Bundy, makes him uncomfortable.  The President sizes Scali up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So they'll remove the missiles, and we'll pledge not to invade Cuba, destabilize Castro or assist anyone who plans in doing so... Nobody dares speak.  It's as if the possibility of a settlement will vanish into thin air if anyone moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think... this may be our first real message from Khruschev.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The alternative, Mr. President, is that this could be a trap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dangle a settlement, tie us down in negotiations, we come up short...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why else would they approach us in this way?  It's deniable.  The Soviets have done nothing but lie to us.  This could be more of the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That may be why Khruschev's introducing this guy.  We've been burned by his usual players in the formal channels, so he brings in an honest broker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That may be what they want us to think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is, Mr. President, we don't even really know whom Fomin speaks for. It could be Khruschev. It could be some faction in the Politburo or the KGB itself.  We just don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the way, Scali, your activities now fall under the secrecy codicils of the National Security Act.  Sorry, no Pulitzer. The gathered men chuckle, only Scali a bit dour but being a good sport about it.  Scali checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, we don't have much time. I'm supposed to meet with him again in three and a half hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it seems the question of the day is -- is the offer legitimate? He moves away from his desk.  The men watch him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it is... if it is, then we can't afford to ignore it. (beat, to Scali) John, we'll have instructions for you in a couple of hours. Scali nods.  Rusk escorts him out.  They wait until the door closes.  Taylor looks over at McCone who nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, I'm afraid we have some bad news.  We're getting GMAIC estimates from our latest low-level overflights. It appears the missiles are two to three days away from operational status.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we don't have much time to play out back-channel communiques. Kenny gives Bobby a hard look.  The President appears unfazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The quarantine, sir, is not producing results.  The Chiefs feel it's time you take another look at our options. The President considers Taylor, then looks over to Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, get over to your old stomping grounds.  Go through everything the FBI has on Fomin.  I need your best call: is this guy legit and is he speaking for Khruschev?  And I need you to tell me by the time I call you, because right after I call you, I'm calling Scali with his instructions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !  A STACK OF FILES slams down beside Kenny on a large paper-covered conference table.  WALTER SHERIDAN, Kenny's investigator-buddy, wears a visitor's pass just like Kenny. Kenny and Walter RIFLE through the folders, super fast, super proficient.  A half-dozen FBI AGENTS work around the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  So, what we've got is this guy Alexander Feklisov, aka Alexander Fomin, declared Consul to the Soviet Embassy, but in reality the KGB Papa Spy.  An illustrious tour of duty during the Great Patriotic War gets him on the Party fast track, various tours of duty in KGB, American postings.  He's an expert on us, and... that's all we've got on Papa Spy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's he talking for?  Is it Khruschev, or is this more bullshit? Kenny stands, runs his hands through his hair, aggravated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you become the KGB top spy in the United States?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gotta know someone. Kenny whirls on Sheridan.  A frozen beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Politics is politics.  Walter. (whirling on Agents) Khruschev is the Moscow Party Boss under Stalin.  Give me their career chronologies! Walter pushes a typed dateline of Khruschev's major career moves, and one of the Agents hands Kenny a list of Fomin's postings.  He lays them side by side.  And for every step of Khruschev's, there's a step for Fomin.  Not only that, but the DATES ARE IDENTICAL or nearly so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time Khruschev moves up, Fomin does within a year... (tracing up the list) Khruschev was the administrator in charge of preparing Moscow's defenses during the war.  And Fomin... was here in the U.S. Kenny's face falls.  But a YOUNG FBI AGENT cuts in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at first. The Young FBI Agent proffers him a file.  Kenny snatches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was an engineer stationed outside Moscow in '42.  Specialized in tank traps. Kenny looks up at Walter.  Walter nods sagely, lights a pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They know each other.  They're war buddies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's thin.  But real life usually is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the table SHRILLS, shattering the silent triumph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to move.  What do you have, Kenny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They know each other!  Khruschev and Feklisov aka Fomin were war buddies!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sure...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't take it to court, but we've got good circumstantial evidence... (off Walter's nod) Walter agrees.  My gut's telling me Khruschev's turning to a trusted old friend to carry his message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Ken.  We're going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few lonely BUSINESS TRAVELERS hang out in the dim coffee shop.  Faint music plays.  Scali and ALEXANDER FOMIN sit with steaming cups of coffee.  Scali, nervous, unfolds a note. Fomin, an expressionless gray spectre of a man, eyes him.  He is, in his boredom, a spy's spy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am instructed to tell you that the American Government would respond favorably to an offer along the lines you have discussed.  If this solution were raised at the U.N. by Ambassador Zorin, he would find a favorable reply from Ambassador Stevenson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I understand you correctly.  If the missiles in Cuba were dismantled, returned to the Soviet Union, and a guarantee was made not to reintroduce them, the United States would be prepared to guarantee that it would never invade Cuba?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is correct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is from the Highest Authority?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  From the Highest Authority.  There are two conditions.  The U.N. must be allowed to inspect the removal of the missiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, of course, the U.N. must be allowed to observe the redeployment of forces from the American Southeast. Scali demurs.  He has no instructions on this count.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the second condition?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time is of the essence. Scali takes a sip of coffee.  Fomin stares at him, intense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John.  How much time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hours.  In 48 hours there can be no deals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scali finishes debriefing the President, Bobby, Kenny, McCone, Taylor and Bundy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He left right away.  Got the feeling he meant business. Kenny and Bobby share a hopeful glance.  Rusk enters from Kenny's office.  And he's unable to contain his excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, we're receiving a letter from Khruschev over at State.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a cluster of folding metal chairs, Kenny, Bobby, Rusk and Sorensen watch a TELETYPE hammer out the message as it comes off the wire.  It's painfully slow, like watching a bad typist type a manuscript.  Ten pages of this is an eternity. To top it off, it's in Russian.  A TRANSLATOR reads it off, word by word to a TRANSCRIBER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...two...of...us...pull...on...the... knot...of...war...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny slams a page of Khruschev's letter on the table.  He jabs his finger at it.  EXCOM listens, intent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's ten pages of sentimental fluff, but he's saying right here.  He'll remove the missiles in return for a no-invasion pledge.  It looks like Fomin's overture was genuine. The President turns to McCone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our early analysis says this was probably written by Khruschev himself. It's a first draft, and shows no signs of being polished by the foreign ministry.  In fact, it probably hasn't been approved by the Politburo.  They wouldn't have let the emotionalism go by.  The analysts say it was written by someone under considerable stress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glad to hear we're not alone. The President eyes the EXCOM members one by one, an incipient smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, gentlemen, I wasn't planning on invading Cuba anyway.  I think we can live with the terms of this deal. There are mostly nods of assent, big smiles around the table. Except from  McCone and Taylor.  The President takes his copy of the letter, flips through it.  He shakes his head, almost unable to believe that Khruschev has given in.  A long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted, I want you to draft our acceptance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long, black car stops at the end of Kenny's driveway.  The door opens, and Kenny steps out.  He says an inaudible goodnight to the driver, and the car pulls off.  He turns, facing the white two-story house with the neat front yard, the lights out.  And he smiles.  Home at last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A screen door squeaks open.  Kenny steps out into the darkness of the back yard.  And there, in her robe, sitting startled on a lawn chair, lit only by the dim glow of the kitchen window, is Helen.  Kenny stands there tired, his coat slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Helen rises, her own care-worn face turned to his.  For a silent moment they gaze at each other, searching in the lines of each others' face for the changes of a long separation. They see them.  But they've been married a long time, and the awkwardness passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, O'Donnell.  You look old. Kenny drops his coat on a table as Helen comes up and folds herself into his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This job's going to kill you.  If I don't first. They kiss, comfortable.  But not too long, and he lets her go.  She looks at him again, sees he's suppressing a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're home it means either Jack and Bobby have finally figured out what a con man you are and fired you, or -- KENNY -- we got a back channel communication from Khruschev this evening feeling us out about a deal.  He confirmed it just a little while ago in a letter to the President.  I think we've won.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A thing like this... who could even think of winning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27TH.  DAY 12. Kenny, in his overcoat, steps aside as a pair of Duty Officers race past him, almost bowling him over. He slows as he nears the doors to his office and the Oval Office, DISCOVERING:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  EXCOM guys, Assistants, dart to and from the offices and halls.  On all their faces grim expressions. Kenny stands there a beat in confusion.  And then Bobby swings out of Kenny's office.  There's a desperate edge to Bobby's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where've you been?  We've been trying to find you all morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen and I went out for breakfast. EXCOM's not supposed to convene til eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just got a second letter from Khruschev.  The deal's off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny and Bobby walk fast for the cabinet room, Kenny still in his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're getting everyone together as fast as we can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does the letter say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They want us to take our missiles out of Turkey along with the no invasion pledge.  It looks like Fomin was a ploy after all, and they were just stalling for time. Kenny is stunned.
direction.name: direction
