direction.raw_text: It gets worse. Kenny gives Bobby a sharp look as they enter -- INT. CABINET ROOM - CONTINUOUS The President, in shirtsleeves, no tie, glances up at Kenny as he and Bobby enter.  Kenny can only bear his look for a second: he blew the call on Fomin.  But the President is clearly relieved to see him, gives him a faint smile. Half of EXCOM, including McNamara, McCone, Rusk, and Taylor barely notice them as they're already there arguing. Kenny sits down hurriedly, shucks off his coat as he joins the conversation in mid-stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My specialists are in agreement: this morning's letter is not Khruschev.  Last night's letter was. (beat) The evidence supports only one conclusion: there has been a coup, and Khruschev was replaced overnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ... Bobby gives him a look: told you things got worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't necessarily mean there's been a coup.  Khruschev's name is signed to the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, come on, Dean!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But at the very least... It does suggest he's been co-opted by hard line elements.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which at the end of the day is the same thing as a coup.  A puppet Khruschev, and a hard-line Soviet government pulling the strings.  No deal.  And the missiles are almost operational. Bitter silence.  They all look to the President.  Imminent victory has turned to ashes.  The President studies his own folded hands.  Ball and Thompson enter, take seats.  One by one, throughout the scene, other EXCOM members join the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, the problem we have is that this is latest offer of theirs will seem reasonable to everyone.  We remove our missiles, they remove theirs. Our Jupiters were scheduled for removal anyway.  They're obsolete, after all. Kenny shakes his head in mute anger.  McNamara and Rusk seem to sense the President's feelings, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, agreeing to such a trade would be tantamount to paying ransom. They'll put a gun to our head again, and expect us to pay again. Kenny looks the President in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't sell out one of our friends for our own safety.  NATO wouldn't trust us anymore, and they'd be right not to. The President sighs in the face of the stern advice.  He nods, expecting as much.  Bobby still can't look at anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So which one of you geniuses can tell me how to explain ourselves to the world? How do we work with them if there's been a hard-line coup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, there is another possibility we haven't considered.  This may not be a coup at all. Everyone of Kenny's instincts jumps.  His head snaps up to listen to Taylor.  Taylor pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's possible that the back-channel overture, last night's letter, and this letter today, along with everything the Soviets have said all along, is nothing more than a lie -- disinformation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Designed to keep us from taking action. Kenny hears the fatalism in McNamara's voice.  A long beat. Everyone stares at McNamara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate to say it, but if I had to bet, I'd bet Max is right.  What if they have no intention of honoring this deal, either? Then tomorrow they add another condition.  Meanwhile, the quarantine isn't working and they're continuing to work on the missile sites. (beat) I think we have to consider issuing warning orders for our forces. They were so close last night... and suddenly Lundahl and LeMay enter the room with the day's briefing boards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President... Lundahl stands there at the end of the table, gray.  He almost can't say it, can't look the President in the face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This morning's photography is in.  It appears the Soviets have commenced a crash program to ready the missiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The missiles site is now more than just dirt and clearing equipment.  It's an armed camp, with missiles, fuel trailers, erectors spaced every few hundred yards.  MISSILE TECHNICIANS service the towering SS-4s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first missiles became operational last night. With a barrage of shouted orders in Russian, and a whine of the ERECTOR's engines, THE MISSILE BEGINS TO RISE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We expect they'll all be operational in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hours: Monday morning. It stops, vertical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The news hits the room like a thunderbolt.  Kenny looks to Bobby and the President.  The blood is gone from their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we're out of time.  We have to go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That may not be as easy as we thought either.  We've gotten confirmation that the Soviets have also deployed battlefield nuclear weapons to Cuba. A pall falls over the room as LeMay explains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we call 'em.  Short range tactical nukes.  It's possible they've delegated release authority to their local commanders for use against our invasion troops.  It'd be standard doctrine. (beat) Our capability to get all the missiles has eroded during our delay with the quarantine.  The good news is that for the moment we know where the FROGS are, and we can target them, too.  But the longer we wait, the hard it's going to get. They all look to the President.  Kenny stares, in a private hell, blacker and more complete than anyone should ever know. In that shocked silence each man grapples with failure.  The Best and the Brightest could not prevent what must come next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we have no choice. (to  Taylor) General, issue the warning orders to our forces.  They will be prepared to execute the air strikes Monday morning and the follow-on invasion according to the schedule thereafter.  I'll need the official release orders on my desk Sunday night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Understood, sir.  We need to step up the overflights, finalize our pilots' target folders in order to be able to carry out the strikes. The President gives Kenny a meaningful look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Permission granted. Taylor exits.  Kenny rises, gives the President an almost imperceptible nod, as he prepares to leave in Taylor's wake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, if anybody's got any great ideas, now's the time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wearing the bulky high-altitude pressure suit of a U-2 pilot, takes the phone from one of the Air Force NCOs who are helping him suit up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Major Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, at the other end of the line, stares out the window at the fall day.  It seems so mild, so unlike war.  And it takes him a beat before he realizes Anderson's on the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?  Anyone there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Major, my name is Kenneth O'Donnell. Special Assistant to the President. Kenny takes a breath, ready to start the shuck-and-jive... but for some reason doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Major, a few days ago the President ordered me to help him keep control of what's going on out there.  I've been browbeating pilots, navy guys left and right to make sure you don't get us here in Washington into trouble.  But you know what?  We're pretty damn good at getting ourselves into trouble.  So instead of riding your ass, I'm just going to tell you what's going on, and let you figure out how best to help us out up here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now mostly suited up, Major Anderson takes the phone out of the NCO's hand.  He nods, serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Last night, we looked like we were going to cut a deal to get us all out of this mess.  Today, the Soviets are reneging. We're going to try to salvage the situation, but a lot of things are going wrong today.  It's making everyone nervous, and it will be very hard to avoid going to war.  Don't get shot down, Major.  Beyond that, whatever else you can do to help us, I'd really appreciate it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Major Anderson waves his NCOs away.  They leave the room. The Major sits on a bench in front of his locker, thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you're up there at 72,000 feet, there's a million things that can go wrong.  Is your oxygen mix right?  Will your cameras freeze up?  Are you leaving contrail... (beat) Those million things are beyond your control, mostly... But you know, when you realize that, there's a kind of peace.  You don't need to be in control. You never were in control in the first place.  If you're a good man, and your ground crew are good men, it's all you can ask for.  And with the grace of G-d, it'll get you through. The young Major smiles to himself, to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sound like a good man.  You'll be all right, Mr. O'Donnell.  We believe in you guys down here. (beat) Thanks for the call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny nods to himself, deeply touched by the man's faith.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Major.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a click, the line goes dead and Anderson walks the phone over to the receiver on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. RUNWAY - MACDILL AFB - MOMENTS LATER A cart speeds down the tarmac, an NCO behind the wheel. Beside him sits Major Anderson, his helmet on, visor up.  He adjusts the mix on the oxygen bottle he's carrying at his feet, breathing in preparation for the high-altitude flight. Up ahead, among a host of service vehicles, sits the U-2.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson switches over to the U-2's oxygen supply as his NCOs belt him in.  They slap him on the helmet for good luck and lower the canopy as he brings his engines up to power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is flight G3132, requesting permission for take-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you've got runway one, you are cleared to proceed to Angels 72.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger that. And he throws the throttle forward, SMASH CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The twilight, in-between, world of the stratosphere.  Far below -- clouds, shining blue day.  Above, stars and the indigo depths of space.  We hang in utter silence. A silver glint appears in the center of the horizon.  It grows larger.  Then larger still.  It is the U-2.  We barely have time to register the rising hiss of its engines, when it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and BOOMS PAST, leaving us standing still. The CAMERA PANS to follow it, but it's already dwindled to a speck, and we feel how fast 600 miles an hour really is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson's gloved hand reaches for the CAMERA HEATER switches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The belly door whines open like a silver eyelid, exposing the camera's lense.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BLARING ALARM GOES OFF IN THE COCKPIT

direction.raw_text: Anderson double checks his position, switches to the autopilot for the stability only the machine can provide, then hits the CAMERA ACTIVATE button on his joystick. BAMABMABMABMA... The camera begins its photography. Anderson watches the number on the film-remaining counter spool down.  He stares out the window.  The towering clouds below rise up magnificent, glorious... a glimpse of heaven. Rapt,  Anderson stares.  And then suddenly a BLARING ALARM GOES OFF IN THE COCKPIT.  It shocks Anderson around to the controls.  It's his MISSILE WARNING LIGHT. Anderson' hands flash out to the joystick, turning off the cameras, disabling autopilot.  He banks the U-2 hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the U-2 turns, far, far below, emerging from the clouds, barely visible, rises a CONTRAIL.  It arcs lazily toward us. A beat, and then another CONTRAIL. Then ANOTHER.  The anti-aircraft missiles creating them are too small to be seen with the naked eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cockpit is a cacophony of alarms and lights, the horizon outside tilted.  Anderson's breath comes fast, rasping as he does his strains going into the high-g turn. He looks out the cockpit window, finds the first SA-2 missile in pursuit only several thousand feet below him now.  He waits. Waits.  Waits, still in the turn.  The black head of the missile now visible. He puts the plane over, rolling out into an opposite bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The spy plane's long flimsy wings weren't made for dogfighting.  They BEND terribly in the rollout.  And then the first missile STREAKS past, tries to correct its miss, but can't and vanishes into the distance at a 90-degree angle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson's breath comes faster and faster as the second missile rises up, now visible.  He puts the throttle as far as it goes, trying to outrun death.  Every second is a tenth of a mile, and every mile shortens the missile's life span. The rising missile drafts aft, closing on the U-2 from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second missile's contrail rises up behind the plane, levels off, and closes on it at a tremendous rate. The third missile rises up in the far distance behind the second. The second missile races up on the U-2, closer, right behind it, can't miss.  Then at a hundred yards, the contrail suddenly peters out, and the missile, out of fuel, drops away. But the third missile closes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anderson glances out the window, sees the spent missiles fall away, and spots the third missile still seeking him aft. Hand pinning the throttle forward, he prays under his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The third SA-2 rides its billowing column of exhaust straight for the tail of the U-2.  This one is not out of fuel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Major Anderson opens his eyes.  He stares out the window at the glorious wonder of cloud and sea and earth below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the missile looms.  We have time to realize it's almost as big as the plane itself before it SHEARS right into the U
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: s tail and EXPLODES in a BLINDING FLASH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny, jogging down the hall, hears form an open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny! Kenny goes over to the threshold.  Inside the office Bundy stands up from behind his desk, grave.  And Kenny knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of EXCOM is there except for Bundy.  Kenny sits behind the President, deeply distraught over Major Anderson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does this attack on our plane represent a definitive, intentional escalation on the part of the Soviets?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Soviets are in control of the SAMs. It's hard to believe with their centralized command structure that it could be an accidental launch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, taken with the events of the past few hours, I believe this confirms our worst fears.  We're now dealing with a hard-line Soviet government, perhaps with Khruschev as a puppet head, perhaps not. In the silence, Kenny reads the faces around the room. They're convinced by McCone's pronouncement.  Kenny's not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could be a mistake. McCone gives him a get-serious look.  But Kenny presses on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need to be positive before we react. Bundy enters the room.  Everyone looks up.  He stands there in the doorway, his face tight. Kenny sags in his chair.  Bundy, of course, has more bad news, and they all know it.  A hopeless beat.  The President just stares at Bundy, unable to ask.  Bundy nods, affirming what everyone is thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a routine air-sampling mission over Siberia got lost and penetrated Soviet airspace.  The Soviets scrambled MIGs in pursuit, thinking it was a bomber.  It got out okay.  Somebody forgot to cancel the mission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddammitt.  There's always some sonofabitch who doesn't get the word. All we need is the Soviets thinking we're bombing them. (facetious) Anybody else? The humor falls on a cold audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, our pilots are in danger. We must order punitive airstrikes against the SAM site that shot down Major Anderson per our rules of engagement. And finally the moment Kenny has dreaded all this time has come to pass.  He looks at Bobby, then at the President.  The President stares at the cup of coffee in his hands, as if trying to read the Fates' design in it.  A long beat, and everyone holds their breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I want confirmation there wasn't some sort of accident first. LeMay clears his throat.  Everyone looks at him, expecting him to scream or jump up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think that's a good idea, Mr. President.  It'll be safer for my boys to get those SAMs on Monday when we get the rest of the bastards.  I can wait a day and a half.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well, then. But he says it without any belief in the words, realizing they're being tied fast to the train tracks of war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alone in his office, shattered, Kenny stares out the window, viewing the distant Ellipse through a gap in the trees.  Kids are out there playing football.  He glances at his watch, and grabs his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny puts on his jacket as he goes down the steps into the bright autumn day, walking away from the White House.  It drops behind him -- his step is faster, more urgent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny walks down the sidewalk, drawn toward the Ellipse.  The sixth grade FOOTBALL PLAYERS sweep forward with a running play.  Kenny scans them, searching, his breath coming hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches the edge of the open field.  And then he spots the name on the jersey: O'Donnell.  It's Kevin. The players relinquish the ball and the offense comes off the field. Kevin sees his dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!  Dad! Kenny manages a smile as Kevin trots over.  Kevin pulls his helmet off.  They stand there a long beat, Kenny desperate to take him up, abandon his post... but he doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, sport.  You winning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. But Kevin sees the turmoil in his father's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is everything going to be okay, Dad? Kenny's forced smile is answer enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Kev.  Everything's gonna be fine. But Kevin knows.  Together they know.  The end of the world is at hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess you won't be coming home tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: uh... Suddenly a car HONKS.  Kenny turns around.  Bobby is leaning out the rear passenger window of his limo.  And he sees what Kenny is doing.  He doesn't want to cut in, but has to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny!  We need to talk. Kenny looks back at his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back out there, kid.  Remember to hit 'em hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about you?  Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back to work. Kevin puts his helmet back on his head.  Kenny watches as Kevin jogs off to rejoin his team.  Kenny turns his back on his son, and strides for Bobby's limo, dying inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny and Bobby stand by their car off to one side of the restaurant's parking lot.  Bobby's Secret Service Agents maintain a discreet distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we're going to make a deal, we're going to have to do it fast.  This is only getting out of control.  The only reason we're not at war this very minute is he's been able to stretch, bend and break his own rules.  He won't be able to keep it up forever. Bobby jams the last bit of sandwich in his mouth.  A beat. Kenny looks him in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Jack wants to trade the missiles in Turkey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Jupiters are obsolete.  They were supposed to have been dismantled last summer anyway -- KENNY -- Jesus, Mary and Joseph.  I told you how stupid it was to float the Lippman article!  But you wouldn't listen to me. What if there hasn't been a coup at all? What if it's you two who invited that second letter by raising the possibility of a trade? Bobby is speechless with rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if the two of you are thinking this trade is your ace in the hole, you're so wrong.  It's a deuce. Bobby's beyond furious.  They catch their rising voices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it's not just me who thinks that. Everyone on this so-called EXCOM is telling you exactly the same thing: make the trade, and they're going to force us into trade after trade until finally they demand something we won't trade like Berlin, and we do end up in a war. (beat) Not to mention, that long before that happens, this government will be politically dead. Bobby simmers for a long beat, thinking.  And boy, does this guy hate admitting he's wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, so maybe we overestimated how reasonable this trade would look.  Okay? You happy?  So now what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So now you've got to talk him out of it. And then we've got to figure out an acceptable political solution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if there has been a coup and there is no acceptable political solution? Kenny stares off at the city, agonized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny enters from his office, finding Bobby, Rusk and Sorensen talking with the President.  The President gives him a brief, meaningful look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever response we send, it will take several hours for the wire to be received by our embassy and delivered to the Kremlin.  So we're looking at early tomorrow morning at the earliest before Khruschev could respond. As Rusk talks, Kenny passes close by Bobby.  Bobby whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets it, but he's pissed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all well and good, but what do we say to 'em?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It depends on if we really believe there's been a coup. That strikes a cord with Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.  If there has been a coup, and there's a hard-line government in power now, then it doesn't matter what we say. The end of the day we'll either agree to their terms, they'll agree to ours, or we'll go to war.  But what if there hasn't been a coup?  What if... what if what is happening is a series of accidents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second letter is an accident?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  The letter is an intentional, but it's having an effect far greater than its authors intended. (beat) What if our Jupiter missiles are just a last minute haggle to salvage something? Maybe a bone Khruschev is throwing to the hard line, not really caring if we reject it or not? (beat) And then these accidents have happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Making the second letter and the overall picture look worse than it really is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Guns of August.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly. (beat) If they're sane and human like we are, then maybe we just refuse, and they'll let it slide, like we've been letting things slide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So we reject the second letter. And Kenny looks at Bobby.  The world stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  We don't reject it... It hits Bobby like a lightning bolt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... We accept the first letter and pretend the second doesn't exist. The President, Rusk and Sorensen stare at him, mute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the exact same mute reaction from the entire assembled EXCOM.  Finally McCone breaks the spell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't work -- Bobby, Kenny and Sorensen start to object, but McCone raises his voice over theirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- because it's wishful thinking!  It's the same wishful thinking that blinded us all these months while the Soviets were sneaking those missiles in under our noses! McNamara shakes his head, intrigued but skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignore the second letter, agree to the conditions of the first...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no reason to believe the Soviets will let it go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Max is right.  Why will they accept it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can work.  If, IF they believe we'll hit them. Kenny, Bobby and Sorensen look at McNamara, grateful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've only got time for one more round of diplomacy.  The first airstrikes start in less than 36 hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we have to make them agree to it. So how do we do that? The President leans forward.  Sensing he's about to speak, all eyes turn to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We give them something.  We tell them we'll remove the missiles from Turkey say, six months from now so that there appears to be no linkage.  We also tell them if they go public about it, we deny it and the deal is off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we do it under the table so we can disavow any knowledge of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's transparent.  The press'll be all over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six months from now, I'm not going to care.  Are you?  We'll deal with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least it will expose whether Khruschev has been overthrown.  We'll know what we're dealing with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if this is a move to appease the hard line, then it may just be the bone he needs to regain control of his own house. Most EXCOM is nodding, agreeing.  McCone shakes his head in disgust.  Taylor sits in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever carries the message has to hit the nail on the head.  Come across as too soft, they'll push us.  Too hard, they'll be cornered and even more dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They could pre-empt. It's a terrible responsibility to bear.  The room is silent. At last Bobby looks up from his folded hands to his brother. The President stares back.  There is nobody else who can do this.  Only Bobby. His brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby.  You know Dobrynin best. Bobby nods, taking up the gauntlet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted, you get working on the draft. Sorensen and Bobby rise as one, head for the doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And make sure he knows we have to have an answer tomorrow. (beat, final) Because on Monday we begin military action against Cuba. Bobby and Kenny exchange a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Bobby emerges from the West Wing in his overcoat, briefcase in hand.  He pauses, tiny, alone.  The West Wing - and all its imposing spotlit power behind him - reduced to this insignificant man on his eleventh-hour mission. And then, out of the shadows, in the f.g., steps Kenny in his own coat, his breath frosting in the late-night air.  Bobby sees him, and knows he is not so alone anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They meet in front of the limo.  Bobby stops, shuffles his things, awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want?  A good-bye kiss? Kenny opens the driver's side door.  The Secret Service LIMO DRIVER peers out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Joe.  Listen, I'll take care of him.  Go ahead in, grab some coffee. We'll be back pretty quick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure? Kenny's nod and look -- there's no arguing.  The Limo Driver hops out, and Kenny gets in.  Bobby stands there outside for a beat.  He tries to hide how touched he is, but can't completely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with you?  Forget how to open a car door?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby recovers, opens his own door, gets in the front seat next to Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, you rich people. Kenny starts up the engine.  Bobby smiles a twisted smile. As the car pulls away, the two men sit in silence, neither willing to admit how glad the other is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . - NIGHT The limo wheels out into the street, carrying the two friends into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby stares out the window at the passing city, the lights the lives behind those windows.  As the car drives on and on, the tension returns.  Bobby feels the weight of all those lives.  On him.  A long beat.  He gazes at Kenny, the only man he could ever admit this to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if I can do this. Kenny glances over at him.  Bobby stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nobody else I'd rather have going in there. Bobby looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody else I'd trust Helen and the kids' lives to. Kenny means it.  He looks away.  Bobby shifts, awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a left. Kenny looks him.  This isn't the way to the Justice Department.  But he complies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We gave so much to get here.  I don't know.  Sometimes I think what the hell did we do it for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because we knew we could do a better job than everyone else. And Bobby, in the silence and closeness of the car, turns on Kenny - anguished, knowing his life is at its climax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know... I hate being called the brilliant one.  The ruthless one.  They guy who does the dirty work.  The one everybody's afraid of. Kenny looks to him, moved, not knowing what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate it.  I'm not smart, you know. And I'm not so ruthless. He looks to Kenny, searching his face, then away, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right about the smart part, but ruthless, well... That breaks the tension as they arrive at the scene:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appears the grim, square lines of the SOVIET EMBASSY.  Police cars line the streets outside it.  All the windows are dark. A cordon of KGB GUARDS in plainclothes stand by the gated entrance.  On the opposite side of the street lounge two dozen WASHINGTON D.C. POLICE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny gives Bobby a look.  Bobby rolls down his window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slow down.  Smell that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just wanted to see for myself. (beat) They're burning their documents. The final duty of an embassy before war...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They think we're going to war.  G-d help us, Ken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lifts away from the limo, turning toward the Embassy, past the Guards, past the brass plate which reads
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: up and up to the roof where black, reeking SMOKE billows from all of the Embassy's several chimneys. The CAMERA races into it.  It engulfs us all.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EMBASSY OF THE UNITED SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS,

direction.raw_text: Kenny squeals the limo up to the curb in front of the Justice Department.  The doors fly open, and Kenny and Bobby jump out, head up the steps to the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby's STAFFERS greet them as they stride down the hall, Staffer #1 taking Bobby's coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, Ambassador Dobrynin is already here.  We have him waiting in your office. They reach the double oak doors to Bobby's suite and stop. Bobby faces Kenny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll whistle up some luck for you. And before Kenny's eyes, all of Bobby's doubt vanishes.  In its place, a severe confidence.  A grandeur Kenny has never seen. It makes Kenny pause.  He beholds his best friend become a man of the ages.  And then Bobby SMOOTHLY opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a DOOR SHUTS OC like a threshold of history.  HOLD ON Bobby's waiting room.  Silent.  Cavernous.  Dim.  Plush carpet.  Heavy drapes framing dark windows.  And abandoned secretary's desk.  A row of sofas and chairs on either side of the room.  Two doorways, one at either end of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits in one of the chairs for visitors.  Dressed in gray.  Prim.  But beautiful.  A secretary of some sort. One of the double doors to the hall swings silently open. Kenny glides in.  He sees the other door shut at the far end of the room.  Kenny crashes in one of the chairs to wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: motionless, silent. Kenny WHISTLES two notes.  Stops.  And then he begins to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Irish tune, O'Donnell Aboo.  He gets a bar into it -- and there's a polite, soft COUGH. Kenny stops.  Then notices the Woman in gray across the room. He didn't see her.  It's dim over there.  She looks at him, expressionless. The CAMERA FINDS: a pin on her lapel.  A RED HAMMER AND SICKLE. Kenny reacts.  Dobrynin's assistant?  His opposite number?  A friend?  Or more than a friend? Here is the face of the enemy.  Not a smile between them. Kenny resumes his ease.  And begins to WHISTLE again. The haunting Irish song echoes in the vaulted ceiling, filling the dim room.  Strange, sad, beautiful.  The woman listens.  And her face begins to soften. Kenny stares at the dark, lonely windows, his SONG striving to fill the empty room. Kenny sinks deeper in the chair, his tune all-consuming... and the Woman's voice breaks in.  Kenny stops, looks over. Her voice is tremulous and beautiful.  Just a snatch of some song in Russian.  She stops, awkward. Kenny stares.  The Woman stares back.  No smiles.  But in their eyes, they each see the other's fear, the other's beauty, the other's humanity. So this is the enemy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you? Kenny glances to the door.  He considers for a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The friend. Kenny breaks the gaze.  He begins to whistle again.  The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: drifts away, finding the far DOOR to the inner office, Kenny's tune stronger, carrying with it hope...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... to the other side of that DOOR.  Dobrynin sits in a chair opposite Bobby behind his desk.  The room is equally dim. And far more tense. Silence.  And then the FAINTEST STRAIN of O'Donnell Aboo. Dobrynin glances briefly over his shoulder at the door. But Bobby, unseen by Dobrynin, can't help the flicker of a private smile.  It's Kenny's presence, and Bobby is the stronger for it.  And then the tune is gone. Bobby leans forward, cool, controlled, masterful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ambassador Dobrynin, we are aware that at this moment your missiles in Cuba are at the brink of operational readiness...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Floodlights illuminate MISSILES, vertical on their erectors, support VEHICLES, clustered across the man-made clearing. Mask-wearing Technicians wave a FUEL TRUCK back to the nearest missile.  Clouds of toxic VAPOR rise from the others. They've already been fueled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are a vital threat to my country. If launched, they would kill 80 million Americans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dobrynin listens impassively, as is his professional duty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother, my friends, my countrymen and I cannot and will not permit those missiles to become operational. (beat) I promise you that. Dobrynin looks out the window.  And then, pained, looks back at Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I fear our two nations will go to war.  And I fear where war will lead us. Bobby acknowledges him with a nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the missiles do not become operational, if you remove the missiles, then there will be no war. (beat) At this moment, the President is accepting the terms of Secretary Khruschev's letter of Friday night.  If the Soviet Union halts construction immediately, removes the missiles, and submits to U.N. inspection, the United States will pledge to never invade Cuba or aid others in that enterprise. Dobrynin stares at Bobby.  Stares hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If your Jupiter missiles in Turkey were removed also, such an accommodation could be reached. The two men move their argument forward with the deliberation and formality of chess masters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The United States cannot agree to such terms under threat.  Any belief to the contrary -- (beat)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: was in error. Dobrynin reels internally.  The only sign on his face is a slight tremor.  Bobby looks up, registers the calculated effect.  And to Dobrynin's horror, the Russian believes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want war... But not so fast.  Bobby folds his hands.  And he smoothly goes from hard-ass brinksman to sensitive deal-maker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: However, while there can be no quid pro quo on this issue, the United States can offer a private assurance. Dobrynin holds his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Jupiter missiles in Turkey are obsolete, and have been scheduled for withdrawal for some time.  This withdrawal should be completed within, say, six months. Dobrynin lets out his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, any public disclosure of this assurance would negate the deal and produce the most stringent denials from our government. Dobrynin grasps the move immediately, understanding the ramifications.  Still he hesitates a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This private assurance represents the word of the Highest Authority?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it can be relayed beyond Comrade Khruschev's ears to the top circles of my government
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.  Our pledge can be relayed to any government official Secretary Khruschev sees fit to satisfy. Meaning this is the bone he can show the hard line.  Dobrynin struggles internally, knowing what Bobby has done, wanting to hug him.  It comes across as agitation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the caveat that it is not made public in any way, shape or form. (beat) And we must have an answer tomorrow at the latest.  I cannot stress this point enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow... Dobrynin rises from his chair.  Bobby rises with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you must excuse me and permit me to relay the substance of our discussion to my superiors. Dobrynin heads for the door.  Half way there he turns back to Bobby, deeply moved.  Deeply grateful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have heard stories that some among your military men wish for war. (beat) You are a good man.  Your brother is a good man.  I assure you there are other good men.  Let us hope the will of good men is enough to counter the terrible strength of this thing which has been put in motion.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OH LORD, THY SEA IS GREAT, MY BOAT SO SMALL

direction.raw_text: Kenny enters the Oval Office through his side door.  The office is dark, only the desk lamp on.  Kenny's gaze moves over the trappings of power: the carpet with the Presidential Seal, the rocking chair by the fireplace, the desk. And on the desk, tucked almost out of sight, sits a small, humble wooden plaque.  It's turned to face the occupant of the chair behind the desk.  Kenny reaches out, turns it around.  It is the Breton's Fisherman's Prayer. It reads: OH LORD, THY SEA IS GREAT, MY BOAT SO SMALL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're out here. Kenny holds on the plaque a beat, and looks up at the open French door to the Rose Garden.  The curtains swirl around him in the wind as he goes through the door and out -- EXT. PORTICO - CONTINUOUS -- onto the portico.  Standing there in the dark, by the white neoclassical pillars of the cloister, are Bobby and the President.  They're holding drinks.  Kenny joins them. The President gestures out across the South Lawn to the gleaming Washington Monument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were just debating who had it worse, us or George Washington and his guys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't have to worry about nuclear weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but the country didn't even exist as a country yet.  It was a mess, and he didn't have a leg to stand on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All he had was his character. The President and Bobby nod at the justice of that remark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does a guy get a rep like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't matter to me.  If I went down in history like Adams, I'd die happy.  All they say about him today is -- KENNY -- he kept the peace. Kenny looks at the President.  The President feels it, and gazes back to him. The three of them stare out at the glittering city.  The grandness of the world lies before them, and they are deciding its fate, and are humbled by the awfulness of it. The silence is beyond power. And for a long moment, they know not to disturb it.  There is nothing left to say.  The President, at last, finishes his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, we never did control it.  Not really.  Not like we think. He looks at Kenny.  Kenny nods.  He knows that now too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we did our best.  Now it's up to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny's limo pulls away, leaving Kenny, coat in hand, at the bottom of his driveway.  He watches it go, silently urging it to return for him with some call from the President telling him he's desperately needed.  But it doesn't. He turns to his house.  The lights are all out. He notices he's CLUTCHING the handle of his briefcase.  His knuckles are white.  With conscious effort, he unfolds his hand, letting the briefcase drop on the driveway. He stands alone, stripped of his friends, his family, his job... and in that moment, mute, impotent in the shadow of Armageddon, Kenny is our Everyman of the Nuclear Age.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen stands in the kitchen, a ghostly white figure in her robe, the windows open and curtain flapping as she breathes the air.  Kenny enters.  He stands in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw you out there.  You want him to call you back, need you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I'm glad I'm home. And she knows the worst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long do we have? Kenny's voice breaks. KENNY If the sun rises in the morning, it is only because of men of goodwill. (beat) And that's all there is between us and the Devil. They take each other in their arms, the wisdom of the atomic age so simple, so tenuous, every human life hanging by such a thread... yet a thread so powerful.  The CAMERA RISES FROM THEM, finding the OPEN WINDOW and the DARKNESS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The RED DOME OF NUCLEAR FIRE rising over Washington.  It roils the air in its expanding, blood-red glory. It is the sun.  The dawn in the East.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PULL BACK THROUGH THE OPEN WINDOW

direction.raw_text: : SUNDAY, OCTOBER 28TH.  DAY 13 into Kenny and Helen's bedroom.  And silence.  Kenny and Helen lie together on the bed.  The light burns into Kenny's half-shut eye.  Kenny is only dimly conscious of the light's meaning.  Until the PHONE SHRILLS downstairs. Kenny is instantly up, launched out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny snatches the RED PHONE from its hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny.  It's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STEPHEN'S CHURCH - DAY THE CHURCH BELLS TOLL in raucous celebration.  Kenny, Helen and the five O'DONNELL KIDS join the throng packing through the doors to the church.  They're all smiling except Kenny who searches fro faces in the CROWD. And then he spots Bobby with his FAMILY.  Bobby grins at him. That makes Kenny grin back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Radio Moscow.  Moscow calling. But Kenny keeps looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The following statement is the text of a letter from General Secretary Khruschev to President Kennedy. Kenny spots him emerging from the Presidential limo, surrounded by Secret Service Agents - John Kennedy.  His
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: also is with him. RADIO MOSCOW (O.S.) (CONT'D) ...I regard with respect and trust the statement you made in your message of 27 October 1962 that there would be no attack, no invasion of Cuba, and not only the part of the United States, but also on the part of the Western Hemisphere, as you said in your same message.  Then the motives which induced us to render assistance of such a kind to Cuba disappear... Kennedy, greeting well-wishers, a brilliant smile on his face, is carried through the crowd toward Kenny and the doors of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...it is for this reason that we have instructed our officers - these missiles, as I already informed you are in the hands of Soviet officers to take appropriate measures to discontinue construction, dismantle them, and return them to the Soviet Union.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the base has been half-dismantled over night.  Fuel trucks pull away, lumping down the makeshift dirt road.  Across the site missiles are lowered, their nose cones being removed.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CLOUD OF DUST FROM ITS WASH FILLING THE SCREEN, WIPING US TO

direction.raw_text: on its transporter, Technicians crawling all over it, COVERING IT with a tarp. A massive Soviet Helicopter's rotors thunder as it lifts off, cargo crates swaying under it, a CLOUD OF DUST FROM ITS WASH FILLING THE SCREEN, WIPING US TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: laughing, celebrating, half-drunk already this Sunday morning.  The President shushes the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!  Hey.  Okay, that's enough. The group quiets down.  The Presidents stares at them, calm, firm.  They sober up quickly.  Kenny listens, expectant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want any gloating.  This is not a victory over the Soviets.  It's a victory with the Soviets. (beat) I want everyone to remember that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny rounds a corner.  McNamara, Bundy and McCone are talking, excited, hushed, standing to one side, down the hall.  Kenny eyes them as he draws closer, and then they notice he's approaching.  Bundy nods him over, confidential.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been talking.  We can play this big in '64.  It's the foreign policy trophy we've been waiting. Kenny sickens.  He tries to listen, but it all begins to blur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we can ride it all the way home next election.  Bet you're way ahead of us, eh? Bundy slaps Kenny on the back.  Kenny is pale.  Is what they're saying possible?  But Bundy and McCone are too wrapped up in their schemes to notice Kenny's distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've ordered crash reassessment of our major geopolitical hotspots.  We've got a lot of new clout, and we can run the table on the Soviets.  Middle East, Southeast Asia... And Kenny, sad, moved beyond all pity and loathing, realizes it is possible.  They haven't gotten it.  He is speechless, helplessly shaking his head.  Bundy finally sees something isn't right with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong, O'Donnell? Kenny can't speak.  Can't find the words.  But tongue-tied finally manages:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you understand? McNamara and Bundy look at him funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Understand what? Kenny just looks at them, eyes filled with sorrow.  They begin to feel uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun came up today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It shouldn't have.  But it did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were lucky we were able to keep it under control. Kenny looks away, unable to bear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every day the sun comes up... says something about us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Says what, Kenny? Kenny looks back at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something... amazing. They just stare at him.  And with secret smiles, superior smiles, they nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Ken.  I understand.  Feels good to win, doesn't it? But they don't understand, and together turn away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you later, Kenny. Kenny watches them, heads bowed in discussion, disappear into the labyrinth of the West Wing.  Kenny turns his back on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President stands at his mirror, tying a bow tie to a tux for some Sunday special event.  Kenny gathers up his folder from nearby breakfast table. Kenny meets the President's gaze in the mirror, and the two men know they have been to the same mountaintop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kenny... A beat.  Kenny stands straight, ready for action, ready for some necessary thing.  Ready to go back into the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...never mind.  See you around, Kenny. Kenny starts to leave, but at the door, turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know... The President looks at him in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...this was what we're here for. The President smiles an ever-so-faint smile.  Kenny turns and leaves the room, vanishing, and as we HOLD on the empty doorway, the simple, whistled melody of O'DONNELL ABOO drifts from the hallway beyond, becoming our END MUSIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Shortly after the crisis President Kennedy ordered a reassessment of U.S.-Soviet relations, ushering a brief thaw in the Cold War.  During this time, the Washington-Moscow hotline was installed to ensure that in a future crisis, miscommunication would not lead to nuclear war. The President was assassinated on November 22nd, a year after the crisis ended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Bobby Kennedy ran for president in 1968.  After winning the California primary, he called Kenny from the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles and told him, "I finally feel like I'm out from under my brother's shadow." Bobby was assassinated minutes later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The members of EXCOM continued  to serve with distinction in government in various capacities over the next three decades. As Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense, Robert McNamara urged containment of the Soviet threat in every theatre of conflict around the world.  He ultimately advised President Johnson to increase the U.S. military commitment to one of these minor backwater conflicts: Vietnam.
direction.name: direction
